sen.j: 日本建築史（にほんけんちくし）では、日本における建築の歴史を記述する。
sen.e: Described in this section is the history of architecture in Japan.
Described in this section is the history of architecture in Japan.
This section describes the history of architecture in Japan.
sen.cmt: 他の文章との整合性を取るために、語順を変更しました。

sen.j: 住宅について詳しくは日本の住宅、神社については神社建築を参照。
sen.e: See 'Japanese Housing' section for the details about the architectural history of Japanese houses, and 'Shrine Architecture' for the details about that of shrines.
See the 'Japanese Housing' section for details about the architectural history of Japanese houses, and 'Shrine Architecture' for details about shrines.
See the section on "Japanese Housing" for details about the architectural history of Japanese houses, and the section on "Shrine Architecture" for details about shrines.
sen.cmt: このファイルに４件、「～を参照」という記述が出てきます。すべて整合性をとるため、修正しています。

tit.e: The beginning of the 'architectural history of Japan.'

sen.j: 江戸時代から建築に対する有職故実的な研究は行われていたが、学問として成立するのは明治時代以降である（建築という用語自体、明治時代に造られたもの）。
sen.e: Study of architecture has been conducted since the Edo period as part of the studies on the practices and usages in ancient court and samurai families, but it was only in the Meiji period that architectural study emerged as an independent branch of learning (the term 'kenchiku' [建築] meaning 'architecture' was itself created in the Meiji period).

The study of architecture has been conducted since the Edo period as part of greater studies on the practices of ancient court and samurai families, but it was only in the Meiji period that architectural study emerged as an independent branch of learning (the term 'kenchiku' [建築], meaning 'architecture', was itself coined in the Meiji period).

The study of architecture has been conducted since the Edo period as part of greater studies on the practices of ancient court and samurai families, but it was only in the Meiji period that architectural study emerged as an independent branch of learning (the term 'kenchiku' [建築], meaning 'architecture', was itself coined in the Meiji period).

sen.j: 最初期の日本人建築家辰野金吾はロンドン留学の際に「日本の建築にはどのような歴史があるか」と聞かれて何も答えられず、自国の建築史研究の必要を感じたという。
sen.e: It is said that Kingo TATSUNO, an early Japanese architect, was once asked what the Japanese architectural history was like when he was studying abroad in London, and that, having completely failed to answer the question, he felt a strong need for a study on the history of Japanese architecture.

It is said that Kingo TATSUNO, an early Japanese architect, was once asked about Japanese architectural history whilst studying abroad in London, and, having completely failed to answer the question, he felt a compelling need for a study on the subject.

It is said that Kingo TATSUNO, an early Japanese architect, was once asked about Japanese architectural history whilst studying abroad in London, and, having completely failed to answer the question, he felt a compelling need for a study on the subject.

sen.j: 辰野の教え子、伊東忠太は法隆寺が日本最古の建築であることを学問的に論じ、ここに日本建築史が第一歩を記した。
sen.e: Study on the Japanese architectural history marked its first step when one ofTatsuno's students Chuta ITO academically explained that Horyu-ji Temple was Japan's oldest architecture.
The first step in the study of Japanese architectural history occurred when one of Tatsuno's students, Chuta ITO, academically proved that Horyu-ji Temple was Japan's oldest structure.
The first step in the study of Japanese architectural history occurred when one of Tatsuno's students, Chuta ITO, academically proved that Horyu-ji Temple was Japan's oldest structure.

sen.j: 1900年（明治33年）、パリ万博に際して岡倉天心を中心に『稿本日本帝国美術略史』が刊行されたが、建築の部門を任された伊東忠太は天心の美術史区分に大きな影響を受け、建築史の大枠を築いた。
sen.e: The "Manuscript: A Shortened History of Japan's Fine Arts" was published in 1900 in relation to Japan's participation in the world's fair held in Paris, compilation of which was carried out having Tenshin OKAKURA as a central figure, and Chuta ITO, being in charge of the architecture section, was strongly influenced by Tenshin's way to classify the history of fine arts, and he established the overall framework of the architectural history.

The manuscript "A Shortened History of Japan's Fine Arts", published in 1900 to coincide with Japan's participation in the world's fair in Paris, was compiled chiefly by Tenshin OKAKURA with Chuta ITO in charge of the architecture section; it was strongly influenced by Tenshin's method of classifying the history of fine arts and his established framework of architectural history.

The manuscript "A Shortened History of Japan's Fine Arts," published in 1900 to coincide with Japan's participation in the world's fair in Paris, was compiled chiefly by Tenshin OKAKURA with Chuta ITO in charge of the architecture section; it was strongly influenced by Tenshin's method of classifying the history of fine arts and his established framework of architectural history.
sen.cmt: "A Shortened History of Japan's Fine Arts", のコンマの位置修正しました。

sen.j: 当時、廃仏毀釈で大きな打撃を受けた寺院建築の保護が課題となっており、関野貞は奈良・京都の主な建築を調査し、それらの建築年代をまとめていった。
sen.e: In those days, protection of the temple architecture which had been badly shocked by haibutsu-kishaku (the anti-Buddhist movement in the Meiji era that led to the destruction of Buddhist temples) was an issue, and Tadashi SEKINO conducted field researches on the major buildings located in Nara and Kyoto to compile their year of erection.

A key issue in those days was the protection of temple architecture, as many temples had been badly affected by haibutsu-kishaku (the anti-Buddhist movement in the Meiji era that resulted in the destruction of many Buddhist temples), and so Tadashi SEKINO conducted field research to record the year of construction of the major buildings located in Nara and Kyoto.

A key issue in those days was the protection of temple architecture, as many temples had been badly affected by haibutsu-kishaku (the anti-Buddhist movement in the Meiji era that resulted in the destruction of many Buddhist temples), and so Tadashi SEKINO conducted field research to record the year of construction of the major buildings located in Nara and Kyoto.
sen.cmt: anti―Buddhist→ハイホンを半角に修正しました。

sen.j: また、建築史学者と歴史家の間に法隆寺の建設年代に関する論争（法隆寺再建・非再建論争）が起こったが、現存する建物の様式論や、六国史などの文献研究はもとより、遺構調査など考古学の発掘成果も取り入れられるようになって、学問の深化が見られた。
sen.e: A dispute arose among scholars of architectural history and historians as to the construction year of Horyu-ji Temple (whether or not the Temple had been rebuilt), which contributed to deepening the study of Japan's architectural history because archaeological excavation results such as from surveying ancient structural remnants came to be taken into account, in addition to discussions on the styles of existing buildings and studies of literatures such as Rikkokushi (Japan's six national histories).

Historians and scholars of architectural history were in dispute about the year of construction of Horyu-ji Temple (and whether or not the temple had been rebuilt), which led to a more in-depth study of Japan's architectural history using methods such as archaeological excavation and surveying remnants of ancient structures, examining the styles of existing buildings and studying literature such as Rikkokushi (Japan's six national histories).

Historians and scholars of architectural history were in dispute about the year of construction of Horyu-ji Temple (and whether or not the temple had been rebuilt), which led to a more in-depth study of Japan's architectural history using methods such as archaeological excavation and surveying remnants of ancient structures, examining the styles of existing buildings and studying literature such as Rikkokushi (Japan's six national histories).

tit.j: 日本建築史の扱う範囲
tit.e: Range of research subjects covered by Japan's architectural history

sen.j: 第2次世界大戦前までは古代・中世の社寺建築が研究の中心であったが、第二次世界大戦後は民家、江戸時代の社寺、明治以降の近代建築と次第に対象が広がっている（明治以降、旧植民地に日本人建築家の残した作品も対象になっている）。
sen.e: Until World War II, studies focused on ancient and medieval shrine and temple architecture, and study subjects have widened after the War, such as, shrines and temples of the Edo period and modern architecture of the Meiji period and after (studies conducted in and after the Meiji period included the works left in ex-colonies by Japanese architects as study subjects).

Until World War II, studies focused on ancient and medieval shrine and temple architecture, but since the War, the scope of research widened to include shrines and temples of the Edo period and modern structures from and since the Meiji period (studies during and after the Meiji period included the study of structures left behind by ex-colonies that were constructed by Japanese architects).

Until World War II, studies focused on ancient and medieval shrine and temple architecture, but since the War, the scope of research widened to include shrines and temples of the Edo period and modern structures from and since the Meiji period (studies during and after the Meiji period included the study of structures left behind by ex-colonies that were constructed by Japanese architects).

sen.j: 身近な街の古い建物にも関心が高まっており、例えば道端の祠のようなものでも、地域の歴史を物語るものとして評価されることがある。
sen.e: Old architecture without standing or reputation are attracting growing interest; for instance, one of those small roadside shrines can be valued as something which tells about the local history.
There is growing interest in old buildings with no particular significance; a small roadside shrine, for instance, is a valuable symbol of local history.
There is growing interest in old buildings with no particular significance; a small roadside shrine, for instance, is a valuable symbol of local history.

tit.j: 日本建築の位置付けと特色
tit.e: Positioning and characteristics of Japan's architecture
Positioning and characteristics of Japan's architecture
Positioning and characteristics of Japan's architecture

sen.j: 日本建築は朝鮮半島・中国からの影響を受けて発展してきた。
sen.e: Japanese architecture has developed under the influence of the Korean Peninsula and China.
Japanese architecture has developed with influences from the Korean Peninsula and China.
Japanese architecture has developed with influences from the Korean Peninsula and China.

sen.j: また近代以降は西欧の影響を強く受けているが、日本の風土・文化に合わせた独自な展開も見られる。
sen.e: Western culture has also influenced Japanese architecture since the modern era, but at the same time there has been development which is unique to Japan matching the Japanese natural environment and culture.

Since the modern era, western culture has also had an influence, but at the same time, a unique Japanese style of architecture has developed that is integrated with the natural environment and culture of Japan.

Since the modern era, western culture has also had an influence, but at the same time, a unique Japanese style of architecture has developed that is integrated with the natural environment and culture of Japan.

sen.j: 柱・梁を基本構造とする日本建築と、煉瓦や石で壁を築いてゆく西洋建築は対照的な存在であり、20世紀のモダニズム建築の時代になると、近代建築の理念を先取りした点があるとして注目されるようになった。
sen.e: Japanese architecture, where post and beam construction is the basic structure, is in contrast to Western architecture which is based on building walls with bricks and stones, and the traditional Japanese architecture attracted attention in the age of the 20th century modernism architecture on the grounds that it had incorporated the ideas of modern architecture in advance.

Japanese architecture, which mainly uses posts and beams, differs from Western architecture of bricks and stones, and traditional Japanese architecture gained attention in 20th century architectural modernism since it was ahead of its time in the use of modern architectural concepts.

Japanese architecture, which mainly uses posts and beams, differs from Western architecture of bricks and stones, and traditional Japanese architecture gained attention in 20th century architectural modernism since it was ahead of its time in the use of modern architectural concepts.

The number of sites that are restored based on the results of excavation are increasing.

sen.j: 縄文時代の遺跡である三内丸山遺跡からは予想以上に高度な建築技術を持っていたことがうかがえる。
sen.e: Sannai-Maruyama site of the Jomon period has revealed the fact that the architectural technology of the time was unexpectedly high.
The Sannai-Maruyama site of the Jomon period has revealed the fact that the architectural technology of the time was surprisingly high.

sen.j: 東大寺（法華堂、転害門など）、正倉院正倉、唐招提寺（金堂、講堂など）、法隆寺（夢殿など）
sen.e: Todai-ji Temple (Hokke-do Hall, Tegai-mon Gate, etc), Shoso (warehouse) of Shoso-in Treasure Repository, Toshodai-ji Temple (Kon-do Hall [main hall of the temple], Ko-do Hall [hall used for ritual, instruction and the reading of the sutras], etc), Horyu-ji Temple (Yumedono [the Hall of Visions], etc).
sen.cmt: 夢殿の解説the Hall of Visionsは法隆寺のウェブサイト英文ページからとりました。
sen.e: Todai-ji Temple (Hokke-do Hall, Tegai-mon Gate, etc.), Shoso (warehouse) of Shoso-in Treasure Repository, Toshodai-ji Temple (Kon-do Hall [main hall of the temple], Ko-do Hall [hall used for ritual, instruction and reading sutras], etc.), Horyu-ji Temple (Yumedono [the Hall of Visions], etc.).

Todai-ji Temple (Hokke-do Hall, Tegai-mon Gate, etc.), Shoso (warehouse) of Shoso-in Treasure Repository, Toshodai-ji Temple (Kon-do Hall [main hall of the temple], Ko-do Hall [hall used for ritual, instruction and reading sutras], etc.), Horyu-ji Temple (Yumedono [the Hall of Visions], etc.).

sen.j: 寝殿造
sen.e: Shinden-zukuri style (the palace based architectural style of the Court nobles' houses in the Heian period)
Shinden-zukuri style (architectural style of court nobles' houses in the Heian period)
Shinden-zukuri style (architectural style of court nobles' houses in the Heian period)

sen.j: 飛鳥時代・奈良時代は、朝鮮半島や中国から建築技術を取り入れた時期である。
sen.e: It was in the periods of Asuka and Nara that Japan borrowed the architectural techniques from China and the Korean Peninsula.
During the Asuka and Nara periods, Japan adopted architectural techniques from China and the Korean Peninsula.
During the Asuka and Nara periods, Japan adopted architectural techniques from China and the Korean Peninsula.

sen.j: 仏教公伝（538年）以降、日本でも寺院建築が建てられるようになった。
sen.e: Temples started to be constructed in Japan too from after the official introduction of Buddhism to Japan (538).
The construction of temples also began after the official introduction of Buddhism to Japan in 538.
The construction of temples also began after the official introduction of Buddhism to Japan in 538.

sen.j: 記録では577年に仏工・造寺工が百済から招かれた。
sen.e: Records show that makers of Buddhist images and utensils and temple carpenters were invited from Paekche in 577.
Records show that temple carpenters and makers of Buddhist images and artifacts were invited from Paekche in 577.
Records show that temple carpenters and makers of Buddhist images and artifacts were invited from Paekche in 577.

sen.j: 588年から609年にかけて蘇我氏が築いた飛鳥寺（奈良県高市郡明日香村。法興寺、元興寺とも）や593年聖徳太子創建とされる摂津国の四天王寺(大阪府大阪市天王寺区。天王寺)が、日本最古の伽藍とされる（いずれも当初の建物は現存しない）。
sen.e: Asuka-dera Temple (also known as Hoko-ji Temple and Gango-ji Temple) built by the Asuka clan in a period from 588 to 609 (Asuka-mura Village, Takaichi-gun, Nara Prefecture), and Shitenno-ji Temple (Tennoji, Tennoji-ku, Osaka City, Osaka Prefecture) which is said to have been founded by Prince Shotoku are believed to be the oldest Japanese Buddhist temples (the original building not existing in either case).

Also known as Hoko-ji Temple or Gango-ji Temple, Asuka-dera Temple (Asuka-mura Village, Takaichi-gun, Nara Prefecture), which was built by the Asuka clan in the period from 588 to 609, and Shitenno-ji Temple (Tennoji, Tennoji-ku, Osaka City, Osaka Prefecture), which is said to have been founded by Prince Shotoku, are believed to be the oldest Japanese Buddhist temples (the original building not existing in either case).

Also known as Hoko-ji Temple or Gango-ji Temple, Asuka-dera Temple (Asuka-mura Village, Takaichi-gun, Nara Prefecture), which was built by the Asuka clan in the period from 588 to 609, and Shitenno-ji Temple (Tennoji, Tennoji-ku, Osaka City, Osaka Prefecture), which is said to have been founded by Prince Shotoku, are believed to be the oldest Japanese Buddhist temples (the original building not existing in either case).

sen.j: 現存するものとしては法隆寺の西院伽藍、法起寺三重塔（ともに奈良県生駒郡斑鳩町）が最古のものである。
sen.e: Among the cases where original buildings exist, Saiin Garan (Western Precinct Complex consisting of Naka-mon Gate, Five-Story Pagoda, Kon-do Hall, Dai-Ko-do Hall, etc.) of Horyu-ji Temple and the Three-Story Pagoda of Hokki-ji Temple (both Ikaruga-cho, Ikoma-gun, Nara Prefecture) are the oldest.

The oldest temples that exist in their original structure are Saiin Garan (Western Precinct Complex consisting of Naka-mon Gate, Five-Story Pagoda, Kon-do Hall, Dai-Ko-do Hall, etc.) of Horyu-ji Temple and the Three-Story Pagoda of Hokki-ji Temple (both located in Ikaruga-cho, Ikoma-gun, Nara Prefecture).

The oldest temples that exist in their original structure are Saiin Garan (Western Precinct Complex consisting of Naka-mon Gate, Five-Story Pagoda, Kon-do Hall, Dai-Ko-do Hall, etc.) of Horyu-ji Temple and the Three-Story Pagoda of Hokki-ji Temple (both located in Ikaruga-cho, Ikoma-gun, Nara Prefecture).

sen.j: 法隆寺西院伽藍は、かつては聖徳太子の時代の建築と信じられていたが、近代における研究の進展の結果、670年の火災以後、7世紀末から8世紀初めの再建と考えられている。
sen.e: Saiin Garan of Horyu-ji Temple was once believed to have been built in the age of Prince Shotoku, but it is now considered, thanks to the progress of the research work achieved in the modern times, that the Complex was destroyed by fire in 670 and was rebuilt sometime between the late 7th and the early 8th century.

Saiin Garan of Horyu-ji Temple was once believed to have been built in the age of Prince Shotoku, but it is now considered, thanks to the development of research in the modern times, that the complex was destroyed by fire in 670 and rebuilt sometime between the late 7th and early 8th century.

Saiin Garan of Horyu-ji Temple was once believed to have been built in the age of Prince Shotoku, but it is now considered, thanks to the development of research in the modern times, that the complex was destroyed by fire in 670 and rebuilt sometime between the late seventh and early eighth century.
sen.cmt: 数字をスペルアウトしました。

sen.j: 法起寺三重塔は8世紀初めの建築である。
sen.e: The Three-Story Pagoda of Hokki-ji Temple was built in the early 8th century.
The Three-Story Pagoda of Hokki-ji Temple was built in the early 8th century.
The Three-Story Pagoda of Hokki-ji Temple was built in the early eighth century.
sen.cmt: 数字をスペルアウトしました。

sen.j: 当時の伽藍配置や技法には、百済の寺院との共通性が指摘されている。
sen.e: It is pointed out that the placement of Buddhist temples and the building techniques employed at that time have some commonalities with those relating to the temples of Paekche.
It should be noted that the building techniques and positioning of Buddhist temples at that time reflect the style of temples in Paekche.
It should be noted that the building techniques and positioning of Buddhist temples at that time reflect the style of temples in Paekche.

sen.j: 遣隋使・遣唐使の時代になると、中国の建築様式の影響が強くなった。
sen.e: Influence of Chinese architectural style grew in the age of the Japanese envoys to Sui and Tong Dynasties China.
The influence of Chinese architectural style grew during the Sui and Tong Dynasties when Japanese envoys were sent to China.
The influence of Chinese architectural style grew during the Sui and Tong Dynasties when Japanese envoys were sent to China.

sen.j: 平安時代、国風文化の時代になると建築様式も日本化し、柱を細く、天井を低めにした穏やかな空間が好まれるようになった。
sen.e: In the times of the aristocratic culture in the Heian period, the architectural style came to possess typically Japanese features, where rooms creating a balmy atmosphere with thinner pillars and lower ceilings were preferred.

During the aristocratic era of the Heian period, architectural style came to possess typically Japanese features, where rooms creating a serene atmosphere with thinner pillars and lower ceilings were preferred.

During the aristocratic era of the Heian period, architectural style came to possess typically Japanese features, where rooms creating a serene atmosphere with thinner pillars and lower ceilings were preferred.

sen.j: 平安時代以降には日本独自の形態として発展し、この建築様式を和様建築と呼ぶ。
sen.e: In and after the Heian period, Japanese architecture developed into a style which is unique to Japan and is called Wayo Kenchiku (Japanese-style architecture).
During and after the Heian period, a unique Japanese style of architecture developed called Wayo Kenchiku (Japanese-style architecture).
During and after the Heian period, a unique Japanese style of architecture developed called Wayo Kenchiku (Japanese-style architecture).

sen.j: 鎌倉時代
sen.e: Kamakura period
The Kamakura period

Buddha Hall at Kozan-ji Temple, Sakyamuni Hall of Zenpuku-in Temple
Buddha Hall at Kozan-ji Temple, Syakamuni Hall of Zenpuku-in Temple
sen.cmt: Sakyamuni→スペルミスです。修正しました。

sen.j: （俗に）武家造
sen.e: Buke-zukuri (Common term meaning the style of samurai houses in the Kamakura period)
Buke-zukuri (Common term for the style of samurai houses in the Kamakura period)
Buke-zukuri (Common term for the style of samurai houses in the Kamakura period)

sen.j: 室町時代
sen.e: Muromachi period
The Muromachi period
The Muromachi period

sen.j: 鹿苑寺金閣（寝殿造+禅宗）、慈照寺銀閣（書院造+禅宗仏殿）
sen.e: Kinkaku (golden pavilion) of Rokuon-ji Temple (Shinden-zukuri style + Zen sect), Ginkaku (silver pavilion) of Jisho-ji Temple (Shoin-zukuri style [a traditional Japanese style of residential architecture that includes a tokonoma] + Zen Buddha hall)

Kinkaku (golden pavilion) of Rokuon-ji Temple (Shinden-zukuri style + Zen sect), Ginkaku (silver pavilion) of Jisho-ji Temple (Shoin-zukuri style [a traditional residential style of Japanese architecture that includes a display alcove known as tokonoma] + Zen Buddha hall)

Kinkaku (golden pavilion) of Rokuon-ji Temple (Shinden-zukuri style + Zen sect), Ginkaku (silver pavilion) of Jisho-ji Temple (Shoin-zukuri style [a traditional residential style of Japanese architecture that includes a display alcove known as tokonoma] + Zen Buddha hall)

sen.j: 主殿造
sen.e: Shuden-zukuri style (Shuden: the main residential building within a walled compound)
Shuden-zukuri style (Shuden: the main residential building within a walled compound)
Shuden-zukuri style (Shuden: the main residential building within a walled compound)

sen.j: 鎌倉時代に入ると、中国との交易が活発になったことで、再び中国の建築様式が伝えられた。
sen.e: As trading with China became active in the Kamakura period, Chinese architectural styles were introduced into Japan once again.
As trading with China increased in the Kamakura period, Chinese architectural styles were re-introduced into Japan.
As trading with China increased in the Kamakura period, Chinese architectural styles were re-introduced into Japan.

sen.j: まず入ってきたのは東大寺再興の際に用いられた様式である（大仏様あるいは天竺様）。
sen.e: The style brought to Japan first was one which was utilized in the restoration of Todai-ji Temple (Daibutsu-yo or Tenjiku-yo).
The style brought to Japan first was one which was utilized in the restoration of Todai-ji Temple (Daibutsu-yo or Tenjiku-yo).
The style brought to Japan first was one which was utilized in the restoration of Todai-ji Temple (Daibutsu-yo or Tenjiku-yo).

sen.j: 天平時代に建設された東大寺東大寺盧舎那仏像は平安時代末期の治承・寿永の乱の中、焼失した。
sen.e: Todai-ji Temple and the statue of Birushana Buddha, both built in the Tenpyo era, were destroyed by fire during the Jisho-Juei War which took place in the end of the Heian period.
Todai-ji Temple and the statue of Birushana Buddha, both built in the Tenpyo era, were destroyed by fire during the Jisho-Juei War which took place at the end of the Heian period.
Todai-ji Temple and the statue of Birushana Buddha, both built in the Tenpyo era, were destroyed by fire during the Jisho-Juei War which took place at the end of the Heian period.

sen.j: 俊乗坊重源は幾多の困難を克服して大仏を鋳造し、1185年、開眼供養。
sen.e: Chogen SHUNJOBO overcame numerous obstacles to cast the statue of the Great Buddha, and held a ceremony to consecrate the newly made Great Buddha image in 1185.
Chogen SHUNJOBO consecrated the newly made Great Buddha image in 1185 after overcaming numerous obstacles in its construction.
Chogen SHUNJOBO consecrated the newly made Great Buddha image in 1185 after overcaming numerous obstacles in its construction.

sen.j: 1195年、大仏殿を再建。
sen.e: The Great Buddha hall was rebuilt in 1195.
The Great Buddha hall was rebuilt in 1195.
The Great Buddha Hall was rebuilt in 1195.
sen.cmt: 前列の多くの～殿の名前と同じように、hallを大文字に修正しました。

sen.j: 1203年に総供養を行った（東大寺盧舎那仏像を参照）。
sen.e: A grand memorial service was held in 1203 (see the section for Todai-ji Temple Birushana Buddha Statue).
sen.cmt: 「総供養」の意味が明快ではありませんが、単なる供養ではないということでgrand memorial serviceという訳語をあてはめました。仮訳です。
sen.e: A grand memorial service was held in 1203 (see the section for Todai-ji Temple Birushana Buddha Statue).
A grand memorial service was held in 1203 (see the section on "Todai-ji Temple Birushana Buddha Statue").
sen.cmt: このファイルに４件、「～を参照」という記述が出てきます。すべて整合性をとるため、修正しています。

sen.j: 重源が再建した大仏殿などの建築様式は非常に独特なもので、当時の中国（宋）の福建省周辺の建築様式に通じるといわれている。
sen.e: The architectural style of the Great Buddha hall and other relevant facilities reconstructed by Chogen was quite unique, which is said to have commonalities with that of Fujian Province and the surrounding area of China in those days (the Sung dynasty).

The architectural style of the Great Buddha Hall and other similar reconstructions by Chogen was quite unique and is said to have commonalities with the architectural style of Fujian Province and the surrounding area of China in those days (the Sung dynasty).

The architectural style of the Great Buddha Hall and other similar reconstructions by Chogen was quite unique and is said to have commonalities with the architectural style of Fujian Province and the surrounding area of China in those days (the Sung dynasty).

sen.j: その建築様式は合理的な構造、豪放な意匠で大仏殿にはふさわしいものであったが、日本人の好む穏やかな空間とは相容れない面もあり、重源が死去すると大仏様も衰えた。
sen.e: Although the architectural style, incorporating rational structure and bold and bighearted design, was suitable for the Great Buddha hall, it was incompatible with the Japanese preference for a space of a balmy atmosphere, and Daibutsu-yo lost popularity after the death of Chogen.

Although the architectural style, incorporating rational structure and a bold design, was suitable for the Great Buddha hall, it was incompatible with the Japanese preference for a serene space, and so Daibutsu-yo lost popularity after the death of Chogen.

Although the architectural style, incorporating rational structure and a bold design, was suitable for the Great Buddha Hall, it was incompatible with the Japanese preference for a serene space, and so Daibutsu-yo lost popularity after the death of Chogen.
sen.cmt: すぐ上の前列ではHallとなっているので、hallを大文字に修正しました。

sen.j: 大仏殿再建に関わった職人は各地へ移り、大仏様の影響を受けた和様も生まれ、これを折衷様と呼ぶ。
sen.e: The craftsmen who were engaged in the restoration of the Great Buddha hall moved to various places after the work, where a new Japanese architectural style influenced by Daibutsu-yo was born, which is known as Setchu-yo (cross style).

The craftsmen who were engaged in the restoration of the Great Buddha Hall moved to various places after that project and a new Japanese architectural style, known as Setchu-yo (cross style) was born with the influence of Daibutsu-yo.

The craftsmen who were engaged in the restoration of the Great Buddha Hall moved to various places after that project and a new Japanese architectural style, known as Setchu-yo (cross style) was born with the influence of Daibutsu-yo.

sen.j: その後、禅僧が活発に往来し、中国の寺院建築様式が伝えられた。
sen.e: Thereafter, Zen monks actively travelled between Japan and China, and Chinese temple architecture was introduced into Japan.
Thereafter, Zen monks actively travelled between Japan and China, which led to the introduction of Chinese temple architecture to Japan.
Thereafter, Zen monks actively travelled between Japan and China, which led to the introduction of Chinese temple architecture to Japan.

sen.j: これは禅宗寺院の仏堂に多く用いられている（禅宗様あるいは唐様）。
sen.e: This is often used in the Buddha halls of Zen sect temples (Zenshu-yo or Kara-yo).
This is often used in the Buddha halls of Zen sect temples (Zenshu-yo or Kara-yo).
This is often used in the Buddha halls of Zen sect temples (Zenshu-yo or Kara-yo).

sen.j: 安土桃山時代
sen.e: Azuchi-Momoyama period
The Azuchi-Momoyama period
The Azuchi-Momoyama period

sen.j: 城郭、書院造の完成
sen.e: Completion of castle architecture and Shoin-zukuri style
Completion of castle architecture and Shoin-zukuri style
Completion of castle architecture and Shoin-zukuri style

sen.j: - 姫路城、彦根城、松本城、犬山城など
sen.e: - Himeji-jo Castle, Hikone-jo Castle, Matsumoro-jo Castle, Inuyama-jo Castle, etc.
- Himeji-jo Castle, Hikone-jo Castle, Matsumoro-jo Castle, Inuyama-jo Castle, etc.
- Himeji-jo Castle, Hikone-jo Castle, Matsumoto-jo Castle, Inuyama-jo Castle, etc.
sen.cmt: Matsumoro-jo→スペルミスです。修正しました。

sen.j: 茶室
sen.e: Chashitsu (tea room)
Chashitsu (tea room)
Chashitsu (tea room)

sen.j: 文化史上、室町幕府が滅亡した1573年から、豊臣家が滅亡した1615年までを桃山時代とすることが多い。
sen.e: In the field of cultural history, the Momoyama period often refers to the time between 1573 when the Muromachi shogunate fell and 1615 when the Toyotomi family was overthrown.
In cultural history, the Momoyama period often refers to the time between 1573 when the Muromachi shogunate fell and 1615 when the Toyotomi family was overthrown.
In cultural history, the Momoyama period often refers to the time between 1573 when the Muromachi shogunate fell and 1615 when the Toyotomi family was overthrown.

sen.j: 天下統一の時期にふさわしく、城郭建築が発達し、権力のシンボル的な天守閣が築かれ、御殿は華麗な障壁画で装飾された。
sen.e: During this period, castle architecture has developed, with castle towers built as a symbolic representatin of power and splendid paintings drawn on partitions, being in keeping with the age of unification of the whole country.

During this period, castle architecture was developed; castle towers were built as a symbolic representation of power and splendid paintings were drawn on partitions to represent the era of unification of the country.

During this period, castle architecture was developed; castle towers were built as a symbolic representation of power and splendid paintings were drawn on partitions to represent the era of unification of the country.

sen.j: また、室町時代に始まった茶の湯は千利休によって大成され、茶室というジャンルが生まれた。
sen.e: Tea ceremony, which started in the Muromachi period, was brought to perfection by SEN no Rikyu, where a new genre of architecture, namely chashitsu (tea room), was born.
Tea ceremonies, which started in the Muromachi period, were developed to perfection by SEN no Rikyu and a new architectural style for chashitsu (tea room) was born.
Tea ceremonies, which started in the Muromachi period, were developed to perfection by SEN no Rikyu and a new architectural style for chashitsu (tea room) was born.

sen.j: 江戸時代
sen.e: Edo period
Edo period
Edo period

sen.j: 数寄屋造り
sen.e: Sukiya-zukuri style (which incorporates a number of tea ceremony house features)
Sukiya-zukuri style (which incorporates a number of tea ceremony house features)
Sukiya-zukuri style (which incorporates a number of tea ceremony house features)

sen.j: 霊廟建築
sen.e: Mausoleum architecture
Mausoleum architecture
Mausoleum architecture

sen.j: - 日光東照宮など
sen.e: - Including Nikko Toshogu
- Including Nikko Toshogu
- Including Nikko Toshogu

sen.j: 寺院建築
sen.e: Temple architecture
Temple architecture
Temple architecture

sen.j: - 東大寺二月堂など
sen.e: - Including Nigatsu-do Hall of Todai-ji Temple
- Including Nigatsu-do Hall of Todai-ji Temple
- Including Nigatsu-do Hall of Todai-ji Temple

sen.j: 宿場等にみられる町家建築
sen.e: Architecture of machiya (a traditional townhouse) observed in a place such as shukuba (post station)
Architecture of machiya (a traditional townhouse) observed in a place such as shukuba (post station)
Architecture of machiya (a traditional townhouse) observed in a place such as shukuba (post station)

sen.j: 民家
sen.e: Private houses
Private houses
Private houses

sen.j: 江戸時代は全般に庶民文化の栄えた時代であるが、建築でも世俗化の傾向が顕著に見られる。
sen.e: In the Edo period, when a wide range of popular culture flourished greatly, a clear tendency of secularism is also observed in the field of architecture.
In the Edo period, when more popular culture flourished, a clear tendency towards secularism is also observed in the field of architecture.
In the Edo period, when more popular culture flourished, a clear tendency towards secularism is also observed in the field of architecture.

sen.j: 茶室を住宅に取り入れた数寄屋造りや、都市の娯楽施設である劇場建築・遊廓の建築などがその例である。
sen.e: Examples of such tendency include Sukiya-zukuri style where chashitsu features were incorporated into housing and architecture of theaters and brothels which were urban entertainment facilities.
An example of this movement is the Sukiya-zukuri style, where chashitsu features were incorporated into residential structures as well as urban entertainment facilities such as theaters and brothels.
An example of this movement is the Sukiya-zukuri style, where chashitsu features were incorporated into residential structures as well as urban entertainment facilities such as theaters and brothels.

sen.j: また、民家も一部は書院造の要素も取り入れ、次第に発展していった。
sen.e: Private houses also developed gradually, adopting the factors of Shoin-zukuri style in part.
Private houses also developed gradually, adopting the features of Shoin-zukuri style in part.
Private houses also developed gradually, adopting the features of Shoin-zukuri style in part.

sen.j: 寺院建築の中でも、庶民信仰を背景に、善光寺・浅草寺など大多数の信者を収容する大規模な本堂が造られるようになった。
sen.e: In the sector of temple architecture, hondo (main hall) of a large scale, such as that of Zenko-ji Temple and Senso-ji Temple, came to be built to accommodate a great number of believers backed up by popular faith.
In the sector of temple architecture, large hondos (main halls), such as that of Zenko-ji Temple and Senso-ji Temple, were built to accommodate a large number of worshippers.
In the sector of temple architecture, large hondos (main halls), such as that of Zenko-ji Temple and Senso-ji Temple, were built to accommodate a large number of worshippers.

sen.j: ※年表は、日本近代建築史を参照。
sen.e: See Nihon Kindai Kenchikushi section (History of Japan's Modern Architecture) for the time line.
See the section on "Nihon Kindai Kenchikushi" (History of Japan's Modern Architecture) for the timeline.
See the section on "Nihon Kindai Kenchikushi" (History of Japan's Modern Architecture) for the timeline.

sen.j: 西洋館・異人館
sen.e: Western-style buildings and former residences of early foreign settlers
Western-style buildings and former residences of early foreign settlers
Western-style buildings and former residences of early foreign settlers

sen.j: - 北野町山本通、銀座煉瓦街など
sen.e: - Yamamoto-dori Street of Kitano-cho, Kobe, Renga-gai Street of Ginza, Tokyo, etc.
- Yamamoto-dori Street of Kitano-cho, Kobe, Renga-gai Street of Ginza, Tokyo, etc.
- Yamamoto-dori Street of Kitano-cho, Kobe, Renga-gai Street of Ginza, Tokyo, etc.

sen.j: 擬洋風建築
sen.e: Gi-yofu Kenchiku (imitative Western-style architecture)
Gi-yofu Kenchiku (Imitation of Western-style architecture)
Gi-yofu Kenchiku (Imitation of Western-style architecture)

sen.j: - 開智学校、龍谷大学講堂、白雲館など
sen.e: - Kaichi-gakko School, Lecture Hall of Ryukoku University, Hakuun-kan School, etc.
- Kaichi-gakko School, Lecture Hall of Ryukoku University, Hakuun-kan School, etc.
- Kaichi-gakko School, Lecture Hall of Ryukoku University, Hakuun-kan School, etc.

sen.j: 建築家の誕生
sen.e: Birth of architects
Birth of architects
Birth of architects

sen.j: - ジョサイア・コンドル、辰野金吾など
sen.e: - Josiah CONDER, Kingo TATSUNO, etc.
- Josiah CONDER, Kingo TATSUNO, etc.
- Josiah CONDER, Kingo TATSUNO, etc.

sen.j: 歴史主義建築
sen.e: Historicism architecture
sen.cmt: ヨーロッパなどの建築物に関するサイトにおける使用例は見受けられますが、正しい訳語であるとの確証を得ることが出来ていません。仮訳です。
sen.e: Architectural historicism
Architectural historicism

sen.j: 分離派建築会
sen.e: Bunri-ha Kenchikukai (the secession school architects group)
Bunri-ha Kenchikukai (the Secession school of architects)
Bunri-ha Kenchikukai (the Secession school of architects)

sen.j: モダニズム建築
sen.e: Modernism architecture
Architectural modernism
Architectural modernism

sen.j: 幕末に居留地が開かれると、外国人の住居、商館、教会などが建てられるようになった。
sen.e: Residences, trading houses and churches for foreign residents came to be built in the foreign settlements which were established in the closing days of the Tokugawa shogunate.
Residences, trading houses and churches for foreign residents were built in the foreign settlements which were established in the final days of the Tokugawa shogunate.
Residences, trading houses and churches for foreign residents were built in the foreign settlements which were established in the final days of the Tokugawa shogunate.

sen.j: グラバー邸は長崎の高台に築かれ、グラバーの指示に従って日本人が建設したものだが、来日した外国人技師によるものも見られるようになった。
sen.e: The Glover Mansion standing on a high point in Nagasaki was built by Japanese under Glover's instructions, but some structures constructed by visiting foreign engineers came to be seen.

The Glover Mansion, standing on a high point in Nagasaki, was built by Japanese people under instruction from Glover, but there were also some structures that were constructed by visiting foreign engineers.

The Glover Mansion, standing on a high point in Nagasaki, was built by Japanese people under instruction from Glover, but there were also some structures that were constructed by visiting foreign engineers.

sen.j: これら居留地の建築に刺激を受けた棟梁たちが明治初期にかけて各地に見よう見まねの洋館を建てた（擬洋風建築）。
sen.e: Stimulated by and learning from these structures in the foreign settlements, Japanese builders constructed Western-style houses and buildings (Gi-yofu Kenchiku).
Inspired by these new structures in the foreign settlements, Japanese builders began to construct Western-style houses and buildings (Gi-yofu Kenchiku).
Inspired by these new structures in the foreign settlements, Japanese builders began to construct Western-style houses and buildings (Gi-yofu Kenchiku).

sen.j: 明治初頭、日本政府は近代化に必要な都市を築くため、西洋建築の技術を得ようと躍起になっていた。
sen.e: Japanese government were making desperate efforts early in the Meiji period to acquire Western architectural technologies in order to establish the cities required for the modernization of the country.
In the early Meiji period, the Japanese government was making desperate attempts to acquire Western architectural technologies in order to develop the cities required to modernize the country.
In the early Meiji period, the Japanese government was making desperate attempts to acquire Western architectural technologies in order to develop the cities required to modernize the country.

sen.j: お雇い外国人として、ウォートルスやコンドルが招かれた。
sen.e: Thomas Walters and Josiah Condor were invited to Japan as foreign specialists in Government service.
Thomas Walters and Josiah Condor were invited to Japan as foreign specialists in government service.
Thomas WALTERS and Josiah CONDER were invited to Japan as foreign specialists in government service.
sen.cmt: 人名の姓の部分を大文字に修正しました。Josiah Condor人名スペルミスです。修正しました。

sen.j: コンドルは工部大学校で日本人建築家の育成に努め、「日本建築界の父」ともいわれる。
sen.e: Condor put his efforts into rearing Japanese architects at the Imperial College of Engineering, and is called the "Father of Japanese architectural circles."
Condor put his efforts into training Japanese architects at the Imperial College of Engineering and was therefore referred to as "Father of Japanese architectural studies."
Conder put his efforts into training Japanese architects at the Imperial College of Engineering and was therefore referred to as 'Father of Japanese architectural studies.'
sen.cmt: Condor→人名スペルミスです。修正しました。原文では「」なので、訳文中も修正しました。

sen.j: 教え子の第1期生が辰野金吾である。
sen.e: Included in the first batch of graduates was Kingo TATSUNO.
Kingo TATSUNO was one of the first graduates of the university.
Kingo TATSUNO was one of the first graduates of the university.

sen.j: 政府による官庁集中計画が立てられると、専門家育成が必要になり、ヨーロッパの中でも日本がめざすべき先進国と考えられたドイツ政府に指導的人物を打診した。
sen.e: Drawing up a plan for concentrated establishment of government offices, and envisaging the need for raising specialists in the field of architecture, Japanese government made an approach about provision of mentors to the government of Germany, an advanced European country which Japan then viewed as her role model.

With a plan to construct numerous government offices and realizing the need to develop specialists in the field of architecture, the Japanese government sought assistance from the German government, an advanced European nation that the Japanese admired.

With a plan to construct numerous government offices and realizing the need to develop specialists in the field of architecture, the Japanese government sought assistance from the German government, an advanced European nation that the Japanese admired.

sen.j: ヘルマン・エンデ(Hermann Ende)とヴィルヘルム・ベックマン(Wilhelm Boeckmann)の共同設計事務所（エンデ・ベックマン事務所）が担当することになり、エンデとベックマンらが来日した。
sen.e: A joint architectural design firm of Hermann Ended and Wilhelm Beckmann (Baufirma Ende & Boeckmann) was selected to assist with the project, and the two men, Ende and Boeckmann, came to Japan.
The architectural design firm of Hermann Ende and Wilhelm Beckmann (Baufirma Ende & Boeckmann) was selected to assist with the project, and the two men were sent to Japan.
The architectural design firm of Hermann ENDE and Wilhelm BECKMANN (Baufirma Ende & Boeckmann) was selected to assist with the project, and the two men were sent to Japan.
sen.cmt: 人名の姓の部分を大文字に修正しました。

sen.j: 彼らは近代国家建設に要する技術習得のために日本人のドイツ留学を時の日本政府に進言し、政府は建築技師として妻木頼黄・渡辺譲・河合浩蔵の3人、石工・大工・人造石左官・煉瓦職・ペンキ職・屋根職・石膏職の高等職人17人で構成された総勢20人の青年をドイツに留学・派遣した。
sen.e: Based on their suggestion that some delegates be sent to Germany to study and acquire techniques required for building a modern state, Japanese government dispatched to Germany a learning mission consisting of 20 young Japanese including Yorinaka TSUMAKI, Yuzuru WATANABE, Kozo KAWAI and 17 senior workmen in such fields as stonemasonry, carpentering, artificial stonemasonry, brick-laying, painting, roofing and plastering.

Based on Ende and Beckman's suggestion that some delegates be sent to Germany to study and acquire the necessary techniques required for building a modern state, the Japanese government sent a learning mission to Germany consisting of 20 young Japanese people including Yorinaka TSUMAKI, Yuzuru WATANABE, Kozo KAWAI and 17 senior workmen who specialized in stonemasonry, carpentry, artificial stonemasonry, brick-laying, painting, roofing and plastering.

Based on Ende and Beckmann's suggestion that some delegates be sent to Germany to study and acquire the necessary techniques required for building a modern state, the Japanese government sent a learning mission to Germany consisting of 20 young Japanese people including Yorinaka TSUMAKI, Yuzuru WATANABE, Kozo KAWAI and 17 senior workmen who specialized in stonemasonry, carpentry, artificial stonemasonry, brick-laying, painting, roofing and plastering.
sen.cmt: Beckman→人名スペルミスです。修正しました。

sen.j: 3年の留学の後、知識と技術を得た彼らのうち数人は後に現東京工業大学の第1期卒業生となり、ある者は美術家となるが、彼らの多くは日本国内の建築分野で活躍した。
sen.e: The mission members gained a good deal of knowledge and techniques during the three year stay in Germany, and many of the members played a lively part, after coming back to Japan, in the architectural circles including some who graduated in the first batch from the current Tokyo Institute of Technology, and some who became artists.

A good deal of knowledge was gained from the three-year mission and, after returning to Japan, many of the delegates played an important part in architectural circles, some became artists, while others became the first graduates of what is now known as the Tokyo Institute of Technology.

A good deal of knowledge was gained from the three-year mission and, after returning to Japan, many of the delegates played an important part in architectural circles, some became artists, while others became the first graduates of what is now known as the Tokyo Institute of Technology.

sen.j: ほか特記事項として、ロンドン大学に留学した桜井小太郎が1892年（明治25年）に日本人初の英国公認建築士の資格を得ている。
sen.e: An item warranting special mention is that Kotaro SAKURAI who studied abroad in London University acquired, as the first Japanese, a license of the British authorized architect in 1892.
Kotaro SAKURAI deserves a special mention as the first Japanese person to obtain a licence as an authorized British architect in 1892 after studying abroad at London University.
Kotaro SAKURAI deserved a special mention as the first Japanese person to obtain a licence as an authorized British architect in 1892 after studying abroad at London University.
sen.cmt: 原文は現在形のように書かれていますが、内容が過去の話なので、訳文も過去形に修正しました。

sen.j: 日本において建築とは、まず近代化のために西洋から学ぶべき技術として捉えられ、芸術・美術と捉える意識は薄くなった。
sen.e: Architecture was regarded as the technology for modernization to be learned from the West, and the concept of viewing it as art has not developed in Japan
Architecture was always considered a technology of modernization which was to be learned from the West and the concept of architecture as art has not developed in Japan
Architecture was always considered a technology of modernization which was to be learned from the West and the concept of architecture as art has not developed in Japan

sen.j: また濃尾地震や関東大震災で煉瓦造建築に大きな被害が生じたことから、日本独自の耐震構造技術への関心が高まった。
sen.e: A great deal of damage was caused to the brick buildings by the Nobi Earthquake and the Great Kanto Earthquake, and interest in the quake-resistant technologies unique to Japan has developed since.
A great deal of damage was caused to brick buildings during the Nobi Earthquake and the Great Kanto Earthquake, which led to the development of quake-resistant technologies which are unique to Japan.
A great deal of damage was caused to brick buildings during the Nobi Earthquake and the Great Kanto Earthquake, which led to the development of quake-resistant technologies which are unique to Japan.

sen.j: こうして、建築はもっぱら工学的な学問と考えられる風潮が強まった。
sen.e: This way a tendency grew to consider architecture solely as an engineering study.
As a result, there developed a tendency to view architecture solely as an engineering concept.
As a result, there developed a tendency to view architecture solely as an engineering concept.

sen.j: この意識は今日まで続いている。
sen.e: This perception is still current today.
This view still persists today.
This view still persists today.

sen.j: 一方、大正中期の1920年に日本初の建築デザイン運動として、堀口捨己・山田守・石本喜久治・森田慶一・瀧澤眞弓等の東京帝国大学建築学科出身者が集まり分離派建築会の活動が始まった。
sen.e: Meanwhile, the first Japanese architectural design movement was started in 1920, the mid Taisho era, by a group of graduates in the Department of Architecture of Tokyo Imperial University including Sutemi HORIGUCHI, Mamoru YAMADA, Kikuji ISHIDA, Keiichi MORITA and Mayumi TAKIZAWA, which was called Bunri-ha Kenchikukai

Meanwhile, in 1920, the mid Taisho era, the first Japanese architectural design movement was beginning with a group of graduates from the Department of Architecture of Tokyo Imperial University including Sutemi HORIGUCHI, Mamoru YAMADA, Kikuji ISHIDA, Keiichi MORITA and Mayumi TAKIZAWA; it was called Bunri-ha Kenchikukai.

Meanwhile, in 1920, the mid Taisho era, the first Japanese architectural design movement was beginning with a group of graduates from the Department of Architecture of Tokyo Imperial University including Sutemi HORIGUCHI, Mamoru YAMADA, Kikuji ISHIDA, Keiichi MORITA and Mayumi TAKIZAWA; it was called Bunri-ha Kenchikukai.

sen.j: ※年表は、日本近代建築史を参照。
sen.e: See Nihon Kindai Kenchikushi section (History of Japan's Modern Architecture) for the time line.
See the section on "Nihon Kindai Kenchikushi" (History of Japan's Modern Architecture) for the time line.
See the section on "Nihon Kindai Kenchikushi" (History of Japan's Modern Architecture) for the time line.

sen.j: 戦争で大きな打撃を受けた建築界は、戦後復興、高度経済成長の中で活躍の場を見出した。
sen.e: Having received a severe blow by the Second World War, the Japanese architectural circles found opportunities for lively activity during the periods of postwar restoration and high economic growth.
Having taken a severe blow during the Second World War, the Japanese architectural movement found opportunities for development during the postwar restoration and periods of high economic growth.
Having taken a severe blow during the Second World War, the Japanese architectural movement found opportunities for development during the postwar restoration and periods of high economic growth.

sen.j: 鉄筋コンクリートの使用が一般的になり、各地にモダニズムの公共施設が建設された。
sen.e: The use of ferroconcrete became common, and public facilities were built everywhere in the architectural style of modernism.
The use of ferroconcrete became common and public facilities everywhere were being built in the modern architectural style.
The use of ferroconcrete became common and public facilities everywhere were being built in the modern architectural style.

sen.j: 地震の多いことが日本の課題の一つであったが、耐震構造技術が進み、かつては百尺（31m）に制限されていた規制も緩和され、超高層建築が建てられるようになった。
sen.e: The frequent occurrence of earthquakes was one of Japan's problems, but the height restriction of 100 shaku (31m) was eased as the quake resistant technologies improved, and as a result high-rise buildings came to be constructed.
Frequent earthquakes was a problem in Japan, but, as quake-resistant technologies improved, the height restriction of 100 shaku (31m) was eased and more high-rise buildings were constructed.
Frequent earthquakes was a problem in Japan, but, as quake-resistant technologies improved, the height restriction of 100 shaku (31m) was eased and more high-rise buildings were constructed.

sen.j: 丹下健三、槇文彦、安藤忠雄など世界的な評価を得る建築家も増え、日本の現代建築のレベルは上昇した。
sen.e: A number of globally esteemed architects came to be produced in Japan, such as Kenzo TANGE, Fumihiko MAKI and Tadao ANDO, and the level of the Japanese modern architecture became higher.
Japan began to foster many internationally renowned architects such as Kenzo TANGE, Fumihiko MAKI and Tadao ANDO, and the standard of modern architecture in Japan improved.
Japan began to foster many internationally renowned architects such as Kenzo TANGE, Fumihiko MAKI and Tadao ANDO, and the standard of modern architecture in Japan improved.

sen.j: 一方、都市の美観という発想は、大正・昭和初期の建築家の一部に見られたものの、戦時体制・戦後復興の中でほとんど影をひそめてしまった。
sen.e: In the meantime, the concept of scenic beauty of cities almost disappeared during the wartime regime and the postwar restoration periods, except being observed in some of the architects in the eras of Taisho and early Showa.
Meanwhile, apart from some architects in the Taisho and early Showa periods, the concept of scenic beauty in cities was all but lost during wartime and the postwar restoration periods.
Meanwhile, apart from some architects in the Taisho and early Showa periods, the concept of scenic beauty in cities was all but lost during wartime and the postwar restoration periods.

sen.j: 伝統的な街並みや過去の優れた建造物の多くが戦災や経済発展の中で失われ、経済性・合理性優先の安上がりな建築が多くなり、スクラップアンドビルドが繰り返された。
sen.e: Many of the traditional cityscapes and beautiful old buildings and structures were lost in the war or during the economic growth, with a growing number of cheap architecture that put the economy and rationality first, and scrap and build being repeated.

Many of the traditional cityscapes and beautiful old buildings and structures were lost in the war or during the economic growth, and there was a growing number of cheap structures that emphasized economic rationality and repeated "scrap and build" constructions.

Many of the traditional cityscapes and beautiful old buildings and structures were lost in the war or during the economic growth, and there was a growing number of cheap structures that emphasized economic rationality and repeated "scrap and build" constructions.

sen.j: しかし「いつの間に日本の都市はこんなに醜くなったのか」と反省する声が大きくなり、重要伝統的建造物群保存地区の選定や景観法の制定など、美しい都市・国土への関心も高まりつつある。
sen.e: With growing soul-searching voices asking when Japanese cities became so ugly, some measures were taken, such as selection of Preservation Districts for Groups of Historic Buildings and enactment of the Landscape Law, and there is a growing interest in the beauty of cities and land.

People began to voice concerns that Japanese cities had became ugly, and so some measures were taken, such as the allocation of preservation districts for groups of historic buildings and the development of Landscape Law, which emphasizes the aesthetics of cities and land.

People began to voice concerns that Japanese cities had became ugly, and so some measures were taken, such as the allocation of preservation districts for groups of historic buildings and the development of Landscape Law, which emphasizes the aesthetics of cities and land.

sen.j: 天沼俊一
sen.e: Shunichi AMANUMA
Shunichi AMANUMA
Shunichi AMANUMA

sen.j: - 社寺建築の細部の変遷を詳細に研究した。
sen.e: - Conducted exhaustive researches on the details of shrine and temple architecture
- Conducted exhaustive research on the details of shrine and temple architecture.
- Conducted exhaustive research on the details of shrine and temple architecture.

sen.j: 伊東忠太
sen.e: Chuta ITO
Chuta ITO
Chuta ITO

sen.j: - 日本建築史の第一歩を記した。
sen.e: - Pioneered in Japan's architectural history
- Pioneered Japan's architectural history.
- Pioneered Japan's architectural history.

sen.j: 稲垣榮三
sen.e: Eizo INAGAKI
Eizo INAGAKI
Eizo INAGAKI

sen.j: - 神社の研究を進め,特に伊勢神宮と出雲大社の心御柱に注目する見方を提唱した。
sen.e: - Researched on shrine architecture, and advocated a viewpoint in particular which focuses on 'Shin-no-mihashira' (the pillars standing under the main sanctuary [honden]) of the Grand Shrines of Ise and the Great Shrine at Izumo

- Conducted research on shrine architecture, and particularly advocated the style of 'Shin-no-mihashira' (the pillars of the main sanctuary [honden]) of the Grand Shrines of Ise and the Great Shrine at Izumo.

- Conducted research on shrine architecture, and particularly advocated the style of 'Shin-no-mihashira' (the pillars of the main sanctuary [honden]) of the Grand Shrines of Ise and the Great Shrine at Izumo.

sen.j: 太田博太郎
sen.e: Hakutaro OTA
Hakutaro OTA
Hakutaro OTA

sen.j: - 中世建築・民家など幅広く研究を進めた。
sen.e: - Pursued a wide range of researches on the architecture of the medieval period, private houses, etc.
- Conducted a wide range of research on the architecture of the medieval period, including private houses, etc.
- Conducted a wide range of research on the architecture of the medieval period, including private houses, etc.

sen.j: 関野貞
sen.e: Tadashi SEKINO
Tadashi SEKINO
Tadashi SEKINO

sen.j: - 奈良・京都を中心に全国の古建築の調査を行い,文化財保護に尽くした。
sen.e: - Conducted surveys nationwide, centering around Nara and Kyoto, on antique architecture, and contributed to preservation of cultural properties
- Conducted nationwide surveys on antique architecture that centered around Nara and Kyoto, and contributed to the preservation of cultural properties.
- Conducted nationwide surveys on antique architecture that centered around Nara and Kyoto, and contributed to the preservation of cultural properties.

sen.j: 長谷川輝雄
sen.e: Teruo HASEGAWA
Teruo HASEGAWA
Teruo HASEGAWA

sen.j: - 四天王寺など失われた寺院建築の復元的考察を行った。
sen.e: - Conducted restoration-oriented studies on the architecture of lost temples including Shitenno-ji Temple
- Conducted restoration studies on the architecture of lost temples including Shitenno-ji Temple.
- Conducted restoration studies on the architecture of lost temples including Shitenno-ji Temple.

sen.j: 林徽因
sen.e: Lin Huiyin
Lin Huiyin
Huiyin LIN
sen.cmt: Lin Huiyin→名前の表記に即して修正しました。

sen.j: - 飛鳥時代の日本建築と隋朝の中国建築の比較研究を行った。
sen.e: - Conducted comparative studies on the Japanese architecture of the Asuka period and the Chinese architecture of the Sui Dynasty
- Conducted comparative studies on Japanese architecture of the Asuka period and Chinese architecture of the Sui Dynasty.
- Conducted comparative studies on Japanese architecture of the Asuka period and Chinese architecture of the Sui Dynasty.

sen.j: 藤森照信
sen.e: Terunobu FUJIMORI
Terunobu FUJIMORI
Terunobu FUJIMORI

sen.j: - 全国の近代建築を紹介して一般に認知を広め,研究対象を看板建築やアジアの近代建築にも広げた。
sen.e: - Introduced Japan's nationwide modern architecture to the Japanese public to make it generally known, and studied a wide range of subjects including Asian modern architecture and 'kanban kenchiku' (literally 'signboard architecture' - a decorative façade with no eave, finished with mortar, copper plate, tiles, bricks, etc which prevailed mainly among the shops in the Kanto area after the Great Kanto Earthquake)

- Introduced modern architecture to Japan, making the style commonly known to the Japanese public, and studied a wide range of subjects including Asian modern architecture and 'kanban kenchiku' (literally 'signboard architecture' - a decorative façade with no eave, finished with mortar, copper plate, tiles, bricks, etc. which was mainly seen among shops in the Kanto area after the Great Kanto Earthquake).

- Introduced modern architecture to Japan, making the style commonly known to the Japanese public, and studied a wide range of subjects including Asian modern architecture and 'kanban kenchiku' (literally 'signboard architecture' - a decorative façade with no eave, finished with mortar, copper plate, tiles, bricks, etc. which was mainly seen among shops in the Kanto area after the Great Kanto Earthquake).

sen.j: 堀口捨己
sen.e: Sutemi HORIGUCHI
Sutemi HORIGUCHI
Sutemi HORIGUCHI

sen.j: - 茶室を思想的な背景のもとに考察した。
sen.e: - Studied chashitsu (tea room) focusing on its ideological background
sen.cmt: 「のもとに」の意味がよく分かりませんでした。著書に「茶室の思想的背景と其構成」というのがあるので「思想的背景を中心に」研究したと解釈しました。
sen.e: - Studied chashitsu (tea room), focusing on its ideological background.
- Studied chashitsu (tea room), focusing on its ideological background.

sen.j: 宮上茂隆
sen.e: Shigetaka MIYAKAMI
Shigetaka MIYAKAMI
Shigetaka MIYAKAMI

sen.j: - 寺院や,城郭建築を建築史の技法を使って再現の研究を行う。
sen.e: - Studied the reproduction of temple and castle architecture using the techniques of architectural history
sen.cmt: 「建築史の技法」の意味が分かりません。一応そのまま訳してあります。
sen.e: - Studied the reproduction of temple and castle architecture using historical techniques.
- Studied the reproduction of temple and castle architecture using historical techniques.

sen.j: 村松貞次郎
sen.e: Sadajiro MURAMATSU
Sadajiro MURAMATSU
Sadajiro MURAMATSU

sen.j: - 日本の近代建築を技術史的に研究した。
sen.e: - Studied Japan's modern architecture from the perspective of technological history
- Studied modern architecture in Japan from the perspective of technological development.
- Studied modern architecture in Japan from the perspective of technological development.
